doc.repnme: Transcript of oral history interview with Michael Lejeune held on November 19, 1985
doc.abstracts: In July 1985, Michael Lejeune was interviewed on behalf of the World Bank Group Archives oral history program by Robert W. Oliver. During his tenure at the Bank from 1946 to 1983, Mr. Lejeune worked in the following areas: in the department of operations as assistant director to Europe (1957-1962) and to the Far East (1963-1964); in the administration department as director (1964-1969); in the Europe, Middle east and North Africa department as director (1969-1970); in the eastern Africa region as director of the country programs department (1970-1974); and for the Consultative Group for International Agricultural Research (CGIAR) (1974-1983). He discusses the creation of specific country departments during the early years of the World Ban, such as the Africa and Middle East departments; the idea that the World Bank considered the economics of client countries as more than just their creditworthiness; and the formal relationship between staff, the board, and the president. His transcript mainly observes the World Bank under the presidency of George Woods.
